description: VFG033579(gb|WP_001063678) (sepD) Type III secretion system secretion switch protein SepD [TTSS (VF0172) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Escherichia coli O127:H6 str. E2348/69]
prompt: Generate the amino acid sequence for SepD, a critical Type III Secretion System (T3SS) secretion switch protein from the enteropathogenic Escherichia coli O127:H6 strain E2348/69. This protein functions as an essential regulatory component within the T3SS apparatus, which is a central virulence mechanism enabling bacterial effector protein translocation directly into host epithelial cells. SepD operates as part of the cytoplasmic switch complex that controls the hierarchical transition from early structural component secretion to late effector protein secretion. The protein likely contains conserved domains for protein-protein interactions with other switch components like SepL, forming a regulatory gate that prevents premature effector release. Structurally, SepD is anticipated to be a soluble cytoplasmic protein with coiled-coil regions mediating complex formation and regulatory domains that respond to secretion signals. The sequence should reflect a protein that integrates environmental cues to coordinate the precise temporal regulation of virulence factor delivery, ensuring successful host cell colonization and pathogenesis.

description: VFG002017(gb|WP_010947516) (fliO) flagellar protein FliO [Flagella (VF0157) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]
prompt: Design a complete protein sequence for the flagellar protein FliO from Legionella pneumophila, a critical component of the bacterial flagellar export apparatus. This protein functions as an essential virulence factor that enables bacterial motility, chemotaxis, and host colonization. FliO is an integral membrane protein that forms part of the flagellar type III secretion system (fT3SS) export gate complex, specifically interacting with FliP, FliQ, and FliR to facilitate the selective transport of flagellar structural subunits from the cytoplasm to the growing flagellar structure. The protein should contain a single transmembrane domain spanning the inner membrane, with both N- and C-terminal regions facing the cytoplasm. Key structural features include conserved hydrophobic regions for membrane insertion and specific interaction domains for complex formation with other export apparatus components. The sequence should reflect the characteristic features of flagellar export proteins in Gram-negative bacteria, including appropriate amino acid composition for membrane integration and protein-protein interaction interfaces. The resulting protein must be functionally competent to participate in the hierarchical assembly of the flagellar basal body and enable the efficient export of flagellin and other hook-associated proteins, thereby contributing to the swimming motility essential for Legionella pneumophila's pathogenesis and environmental persistence.

description: VFG000387(gb|WP_002229794) (sycN) chaperone for YopN [TTSS (VF0140) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Yersinia pestis CO92]
prompt: Design a functional chaperone protein for the Yersinia pestis Type III Secretion System (TTSS). This protein, SycN, is essential for the virulence of Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of plague, by specifically binding to and stabilizing the YopN effector protein. SycN functions as a specialized chaperone that prevents premature aggregation and degradation of YopN in the bacterial cytoplasm, facilitates its efficient translocation through the TTSS needle complex, and ensures proper targeting to host cells. The protein should contain characteristic chaperone domains with hydrophobic binding pockets for YopN interaction, conserved alpha-helical regions for structural stability, and specific recognition motifs for TTSS apparatus engagement. It must maintain optimal stability for intracellular function while exhibiting high specificity for YopN binding without interfering with other TTSS components. The structural architecture should support transient complex formation with YopN and efficient release at the translocation interface.

description: VFG002450(gb|WP_004533397) (bipB) Type III secretion system translocator protein BipB [Bsa T3SS (VF0428) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Burkholderia pseudomallei K96243]
prompt: Generate the amino acid sequence for BipB, a critical Type III secretion system translocator protein from Burkholderia pseudomallei. This protein functions as an essential virulence factor in the Bsa T3SS effector delivery system, forming part of the translocation pore complex that enables direct injection of bacterial effector proteins into host cells. BipB should contain conserved domains characteristic of T3SS translocators, including transmembrane regions for membrane insertion and pore formation, as well as domains that facilitate interaction with partner translocator proteins to assemble the functional translocation apparatus. The protein likely exhibits an amphipathic nature with both hydrophobic membrane-spanning segments and hydrophilic regions that interact with host cell membranes and other T3SS components. Structurally, BipB should possess features enabling oligomerization to form the translocation channel, with specific motifs that recognize and guide effector proteins through the secretion apparatus. The sequence must reflect the protein's role in breaching host cell membranes during infection, facilitating the delivery of virulence factors that enable intracellular survival and pathogenesis of this dangerous bacterial pathogen.

description: VFG002019(gb|WP_013101527) (fliM) flagellar motor switch protein FliM [Flagella (VF0157) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]
prompt: Design a flagellar motor switch protein FliM from Legionella pneumophila, a critical virulence factor enabling this opportunistic pathogen's motility and environmental persistence. This protein functions as an essential component of the flagellar basal body's C-ring structure, where it mediates directional switching between clockwise and counterclockwise flagellar rotation in response to chemotactic signals. The protein should contain multiple FliM domains arranged to form the switch complex interface, with conserved residues for binding the response regulator CheY-P and interacting with other switch proteins FliG and FliN. Structure should feature characteristic Î±-helical bundles and Î²-sheets forming the compact, globular domains typical of bacterial switch complexes. Include the conserved GXXXS motif involved in CheY binding and the hydrophobic patches essential for proper assembly within the C-ring. The protein must maintain the appropriate molecular weight and pI for integration into the flagellar motor apparatus, with surface properties enabling dynamic conformational changes during rotational switching while maintaining structural stability within the bacterial cytoplasm.

description: VFG050901(gb|WP_005119983.1) (cpaA) metalloendopeptidase CpaA [CpaA (VF1336) - Exoenzyme (VFC0251)] [Acinetobacter baumannii BJAB0715]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the CpaA metalloendopeptidase virulence factor from Acinetobacter baumannii. This protein functions as a critical exoenzyme in the bacterial pathogenesis arsenal, specifically as a zinc-dependent metalloprotease that targets and cleaves host proteins to facilitate tissue invasion, immune evasion, and nutrient acquisition. The protein should contain characteristic metallopeptidase domains, including the conserved HEXXH zinc-binding motif essential for catalytic activity, and likely features additional domains for substrate recognition and binding. Structurally, it should adopt a globular fold typical of metalloendopeptidases, with the active site positioned to accommodate diverse protein substrates. As an exoenzyme, it must include an N-terminal secretion signal peptide for export via the bacterial secretion system, and the mature protein should exhibit optimal stability and activity in the extracellular environment. The sequence should reflect the adaptation to human host conditions, with appropriate physicochemical properties for functioning in host tissues during infection.
